awd_titl_txt: SPX: Collaborative Research: Automated Synthesis of Extreme-Scale Computing Systems Using Non-Volatile Memory
awd_abstract_narration:
The project investigates the design of a scalable computing infrastructure that uses nanoscale non-volatile memory (NVM) devices for both storage and computation. The project's novelties are (i) the use of multiple parallel flows of current through naturally occurring sneak paths in NVM crossbars for computation; (ii) the replacement of slow organic expert-driven discovery of flow-based computing designs by automated synthesis techniques for accelerated discovery of novel NVM crossbar designs; and (iii) a pervasive focus on fault-tolerance throughout the design of exact, approximate and stochastic flow-based computing designs. The project's impacts are (i) the design of an end-to-end framework that maps compute-intensive kernels written in a high-level programming language onto nanoscale NVM crossbar designs and (ii) the creation of a new scalable capability to perform exact and approximate in-memory digital computations on fault-prone nanoscale NVM crossbars. The team of computer scientists and nanoscience researchers is creating flow-based computing designs for four benchmark problems: the Feynman grand prize problem, computer vision, basic linear algebra, and simulation of dynamical systems. The automatically synthesized NVM crossbar designs are being evaluated using high-performance simulations and experimental benchmarking in a modern nanotechnology laboratory. 

Computing using multiple parallel flows of current through data stored in nanoscale crossbars is often fast and more energy-efficient, but the design of such crossbars is highly unintuitive for human designers. The project explores a combination of formal methods for checking satisfiability of Boolean formulae, and artificial intelligence techniques such as best-first search, to automatically synthesize NVM crossbar designs from specifications written in a high-level programming language. The team of computer scientists and nanoscience researchers is pursuing a transformative agenda for extreme-scale computing by leveraging memory devices in NVM crossbars as structurally-constrained fault-prone distributed nano-stores of data, and exploiting the natural parallel flow of current through NVM crossbars for computing over data stored in the distributed nano-stores. The NVM crossbar designs generated from OpenCV, LAPACK, and ODEINT programs are evaluated using the Xyce circuit simulation software and subsequently fabricated for experimental benchmarking. By combining storage and computation on the same device, the project circumvents the von Neumann barrier between the processor and the memory and creates scalable solutions for extreme-scale computing on fault-prone NVM crossbars without introducing substantial changes to the programming model.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project advanced the automated synthesis and design of computing systems that leverage emerging Non-Volatile Memory (NVM) technologies, such as nanoscale memristors. The research studied new architectures and algorithms for exploring the potential of NVM devices, such as memristors, for developing flow-based computing. Traditional computing based on the von Neumann paradigm has an architecture with separate memory and processor units, and computing inherently involves the transfer of data between memory and processor. This movement of data to and from the memory creates both a performance bottleneck and consumes significant amounts of energy. On the other hand, the flow-based computing approach performs computations directly within the memory by exploiting the non-volatile nature of the NVM devices. The research under this project laid the foundation for a new family of next-generation computing systems by integrating approaches from formal methods, artificial intelligence (AI), and nanotechnology. The work developed new computational frameworks to address challenges in parallel computation with nanoscale NVM devices such as memristors and directly addressed key goals such as energy efficiency, reliability, and device-level parallel processing.

The research focused on automatically synthesizing and evaluating dense memory arrays containing both NVM devices such as memristors and transistors. These crossbars or arrays can store bits of information and can be programmed to low or high resistance levels, enabling a new form of computation using sneak paths or current flows through paths of least resistance. The project demonstrated how these naturally occurring current flows in nanoscale crossbars could be leveraged to process data and, hence, presented a method for computation within memory.

The project unified data storage and processing into a single framework that leverages device-level parallelism for performing computations. The project created new nanoscale architectures and electronic design automation (EDA) algorithms for flow-based computing that directly addressed challenges such as variability and reliability in nanoscale devices. The project verified the correctness of the designed nanoscale architectures and EDA algorithms using applications such as numerical computations and image processing. 

The broader impacts of this work may lead to the creation of more sustainable computing technologies by eliminating the processor-memory divide and directly addressing the issue of energy consumption. The research creates new opportunities to facilitate energy-saving improvements in the deployment of AI, foundation models, and the Internet of Things (IoT). The project created significant educational opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students, introducing them to the intellectually stimulating world of device-level parallelism in nanoscale crossbar computing.
